Syntax

The Language Reference & Guide aims to be â€“ as the title suggests â€“ a reference and guide in one. Since a programming language needs formal definitions, youâ€™ll see syntactic definitions from time to time. The notation used and the most basic syntactic definitions are described in this chapter.

Hint

If you donâ€™t really care about syntactic definitions, no worries! You should be able to follow along without problems. Just skip this chapter and ignore them.

Notation

The Language Reference & Guide uses an enhanced, modified BNF grammar notation:

hippo âŸ¶ rhinoceros ğŸ¥˜
panther âŸ¶ [ğŸ] hyena | ğŸ®

The first line of the above example defines a rule called hippo, which states that a hippo consists of a rhinoceros, which is another rule as indicated by the purple background, and the emoji ğŸ¥˜.

Each rule begins with a name and âŸ¶ (read â€œconsists ofâ€). A vertical bar (|) is used to separate alternatives. Furthermore, rules can be broken into multiple lines starting with the same name. Parts enclosed in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional: they can occur but do not have to.

Document Syntax

Every Emojicode source code document consists of any number of document-statements.

document-statement âŸ¶ package-import | ğŸ“» | include | version
document-statement âŸ¶ [documentation-comment] type-definition
document-statement âŸ¶ start-flag
include âŸ¶ ğŸ“œ string-literal
start-flag âŸ¶ ğŸ return-type block
type-definition âŸ¶ class-definition | value-type-definition | extension
type-definition âŸ¶ protcol-definition | enum-definition

start-flag was already described in the previous chapter. All other rules will be explained in detail later on.

Statement and Expression

The smallest standalone elements of Emojicodeâ€™s normal program code is called statement.

statement âŸ¶ expression | frozen-declaration | assignment | declaration
frozen-declaration âŸ¶ ğŸ¦ variable expression
assignment âŸ¶ ğŸ® variable expression | ğŸ® method-emoji variable arguments
declaration âŸ¶ ğŸ° variable type
expression âŸ¶ numeric-literal | ğŸ‘ | ğŸ‘ | symbol-literal | string-literal
string-literal âŸ¶ except ğŸ”¤ | string-escape-sequence
